results.title: The Sun goes to work...at home
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
It looks like any other suburban Australian house, but in fact it’s a highly efficient laboratory built in Melbourne for the CSIRO. The purpose is to see how much fuel costs can be reduced by a combination of good insulation, efficient design and an innovative solar heating system.

results.title: Solar power for industry
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
The industrial use of solar energy and its applications in a soft drink factory at Queanbeyan, NSW. A great deal of energy is used by factories. Solar industrial process heating can save a lot of the oil used to generate heat and thus help Australia aim for self-sufficiency in fuel by the turn of the century.

results.title: Siroseeder
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Siroseeder is a machine designed to spray a herbicide, cultivate the soil in narrow rows, insert seed and fertilizer at a predetermined depth, replace the soil and press it down lightly. Normally. farmers could use four implements and make up to eight passes to do the same job. If these and other experiments are fruitful, inputs of time, labour and fuel will fall dramatically, as will the risk of soil erosion.

results.title: Robots for Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
A brief look at the work being carried out by the CSIRO in programming computers to carry out functions in the manufacturing industries. Also raises issues regarding the changing face of the worplace. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Quest for a better battery
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Although petrol saving electric vehicles are making something of a comeback, they suffer from one major drawback, namely the poor performance of conventional lead acid batteries. Researchers at CSIRO’s Division of Mineral Chemistry are working to improve the performance of lead acid batteries made with nickel zinc or lithium plates.

results.title: Predation of cossid moth larvae by yellow-tailed black cockatoos
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Shows how the yellow-tailed black cockatoo extracts cossid moth larvae from the trunks of eucalypts and covers other aspects of the behaviour of the bird and its prey, emphasizing the role of evolutionary adaptation. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: Pollution from chimney stacks
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
CSIRO’s research on pollution from chimney stacks: fly ash (a fine grey powder produced whenever coal is bunrt). Coal power stations conventionally use electrostatic precipitators to remove fly ash before its released into the atmosphere. The CSIRO has developed a more efficient containment of fly ash effectively reducing pollution and producing more ingredients for cement manufacture.

results.title: Please don't pick the daisies
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
The Snowy Mountains of South East Australia, despite their rugged, unchanging appearance are, in reality, quite fragile and quite sensitive to the forces of nature and the presence of people. The wild beauty of Kosciusko’s alpine flora is recorded by a research team for a new book.

results.title: Operation flower pot
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
The CSIRO is currently involved in the unravelling of the intricacies of the complex ecosystems of the South Australian forest. The film shows an experiment being conducted to determine and measure how plants use water in the forest. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: An Open book for the disabled
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Displays an automated microfiche reader developed at CSIRO’s Division of Manufacturing Technology in Adelaide, which promises to make the printed word more readily accessible to the physically handicapped.
